headline.main: IS SUBLIMINAL PERSUASION A MENACE?  EVIDENTLY NOT

docs.lead_paragraph: A quarter of a century after the issue was first raised, battles rage anew over the power of subliminal perception and how extensively this means of hidden persuasion may be used to affect human feelings and behavior. Public concern has focused on such ''1984'' questions as whether people are being influenced by invisible exhortations to ''eat popcorn'' flashed between the frames of movie films, or whether the word ''sex'' is imprinted in microscopic type on every Ritz cracker to make the crackers more appealing, or whether minds are being manipulated by inaudible messages broadcast among the sounds of Muzak. Most major advertisers have disavowed the use of subliminal techniques, though it is impossible to verify their contentions since, by definition, subliminal messages are beyond the limits of conscious perception. Amid claims and counterclaims for the power and pervasiveness of subliminal techniques, little scientific evidence has accumulated to show that either exists. Nearly all studies asserting a dramatic effect of subliminally presented information have failed the crucial test of scientific replication.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The lawsuit filed by Norml to stop the killing of marijuana plants in Florida with the herbicide paraquat (news story July 20) is based on specious reasoning. The pro-marijuana lobby says it is concerned about adverse health effects of smoking an illegal harvest that has been sprayed with the herbicide.
